metadata.title: Influence of pre-added NaOH on the microstructure of Au–CeO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst and its activity for benzene oxidation

Fig. 1 TEM pictures of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2 with different NaOH pre-adding fraction. Fig. 2 XRD analysis of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2 catalysts with different NaOH pre-adding fraction (x is NaOH pre-adding fraction: A: 0%; B: 5%; C: 10%; D: 15%; E: 20%). Fig. 3 Catalytic performance of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–x% catalysts in benzene oxidation (x is fraction of pre-added NaOH: A: 0%; B: 5%; C: 10%; D: 15%; E: 20%; F: 9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2). Fig. 4 Comparison of T 90 and crystallite size of Au. Fig. 5 Raman analysis of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–x% catalysts (x is fraction of pre-added NaOH: A: 0%; B: 5%; C: 10%; D: 15%; E: 20%; F: 9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2). Fig. 6 Comparison of T 10 and red shift of F 2g peak. Fig. 7 Effects of ion doping on the low-temperature activity of 18CeO2/SiO2 (I) and 4CeO2/SiO2 (II) catalysts. Fig. 8 Comparison of T 10 and red shift of F 2g peak of ions doping catalysts (mole ratio of Ce/Si was 0.04 (A); 0.18 (B)). Table 1 Element properties of doping ions. Elements Cu Mn Zr Au Ce Valence state +2 +2 +4 +3 +4 Ionic radius (pm) 73 67 72 85 87 Influence of pre-added NaOH on the microstructure of Au–CeO2 catalyst and its activity for benzene oxidation Xin Jiang a ⁎ Jiefeng Hua a Hui Deng b Zhongbiao Wu c ⁎⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China b China Academy of Engineering Physics, Mianyang 621900, China China Academy of Engineering Physics Mianyang 621900 China c College of Environmental and Resource Sciences, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China College of Environmental and Resource Sciences, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 57187952828; fax: +86 57187951227. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The low-temperature activity of benzene oxidation on Au–CeO2/SiO2 and the red-shift of F 2g peak of CeO2 presented a similar tendency with increase of pre-addition amount of NaOH. Au–CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by Adsorbed-Layer Reactor Technique and characterized by TEM, XRD and Raman spectroscopy. It was found the pre-addition of NaOH changed the hydrolysis of HAuCl4 in adsorbed layer and then regulated the morphology and microstructure of Au and CeO2. In the catalysis of benzene oxidation, with the increase of pre-addition amount of NaOH, the high-temperature activity increased monotonously, which was consistent with the change of crystallite size of Au. However, the low-temperature activity presented a maximum with increase of pre-addition amount of NaOH, which was verified being agreement with the change of red-shift of F 2g peak of CeO2. The results showed that the high-temperature activity depended on Au size and the low-temperature activity was affected by CeO2 microstructure. The experiment of metal ion doping offered another proof. Keywords Au–CeO2 catalyst Interaction between components Micro-structure Benzene oxidation 1 Introduction The catalytic performance of nanometer scale gold depends largely on its morphology which is impacted strongly by supports. Further studies showed that some support, like reducible oxides, could act not only as structural promoter, but also as co-catalyst. CeO2 was typical of that [1–3]. In Au–CeO2 catalysts, one role of CeO2 is to improve gold dispersion and to enhance the support more stable against thermal sintering. Another important function of CeO2 is from the redox properties of the Ce3+/Ce4+ pair, which makes CeO2 participate in catalytic process. Based on these features, gold supported on ceria had been used to carry out many reactions, such as CO oxidation [1–3], WGS reaction [4,5], combustion of VOCs [3,6,7], etc. The size and surface area of CeO2 remarkably affected the catalytic activity of gold catalyst. Lai's research [3] showed that gold supported on high surface area CeO2 performed much better than that supported on low surface area CeO2 in both CO and benzene oxidation. Carrettin et al. [2] indicated that nanocrystalline CeO2 increases the activity of Au for CO oxidation by two orders of magnitude. In our former work [8], nanometer scale Au–CeO2 and CeO2 were well scattered on the surface of silica and both catalysts with and without Au showed good and similar low-temperature catalytic activity, which seemed implying the effect of CeO2 at lower temperature was dominant. These catalytic behaviors of CeO2 manifest there is a complex interaction between Au and CeO2. Figuring out the mechanism of the interaction is important to realize the catalysis of Au–CeO2 as well as to develop new catalyst. In this paper, we approached the interaction between Au and CeO2 by means of regulating microstructure of Au–CeO2 catalysts prepared by the Adsorbed-Layer Reactor Technique (ALRT) [8–10], and then attempted to establish the relation between the change of structure and the catalytic performance in benzene oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Hydrophilic silica (SiO2; Degussa AEROSIL200, average size 12nm, specific area 200m2/g), ethanol (C2H5OH; AR, Hangzhou Xiaoshan Chemical Reagent Ltd.), cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)2·6H2O; AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), sodium hydroxide (NaOH; AR, Hangzhou Chemical Reagent Ltd.), Gold(III) chloride (HAuCl4·4H2O; AR, Shanghai Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), sodium borohydride (NaBH4; AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.), copper acetate (Cu(Ac)2·1H2O; AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), manganese acetate (Mn(Ac)2·4H2O; AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), zirconium nitrate (Zr(NO3)4·5H2O; AR, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.). 2.2 Synthesis process The synthesis of the catalyst was carried out through two steps, the modification of SiO2 with CeO2 to change isoelectric point [8] and then formation of Au–CeO2 on CeO2/SiO2. At the first step, 0.5g SiO2 baked at 120°C for 2h was well-dispersed in 150mL absolute ethyl alcohol. Then 1mL water and 0.09g NaOH dissolved in 50mL ethanol were added successively. Because of selective adsorption capacity of SiO2, a water-rich adsorption layer formed gradually on the supporter surface. The sodium hydroxide distributed itself between adsorbed-layer and ethanol bulk. The adsorption equilibrium was attained in 12h under stirring and 0°C conditions. Then, 0.33g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O corresponding to NaOH dissolved in 50mL ethanol was slowly added dropwise to the reaction system in 30min. The precursor diffused into the adsorbed-layer and reacted with OH−. As a result, SiO2 was evenly modified by Ce species and sample 9CeO2/SiO2 (mole ratio of Ce/Si was 9%) was obtained. At the second step, 0.05g HAuCl4·4H2O and 0.33g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 50mL ethanol, and 0.09g NaOH was dissolved in another 50mL ethanol, then these two solution added dropwise into the solution of first step in 30min. By this process, the hydrolysis of HAuCl4 and the deposition of CeO2 took place simultaneously. The degree of hydrolysis of HAuCl4 could be regulated by concentration of OH− in the adsorption layer and the interaction between Au and CeO2 could change. After 1h reaction, 0.005g NaBH4 dissolved in 50mL ethanol was added dropwise in 30min. After reacting for another 30min, the purple product 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2 (mole ratio of Au/Si was 1.5%) was gained by several centrifugation–redispersion-washing cycles, then was dried at 100°C. In order to change the interaction between Au and CeO2, part of NaOH was added before the addition of HAuCl4–Ce(NO3)3 solution. The concentration of OH− in the adsorption layer of the second step was regulated by pre adding part of NaOH and the hydrolysis of HAuCl4 was changed. The resulted products were named as 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–x% (x% means the fraction of the pre added NaOH). The contents of Au and Ce in the filter liquor were measured by ICP-MS. The residue Au and Ce were less than 0.1% and 0.5%, implying most of them were loaded on silica. 2.3 Catalyst characterization (A) Transmission electron microscopy (TEM): One drop of an ultrasono-mixed, dilute alcohol suspension of the “as-prepared” samples was placed on a carbon-coated grid, and after evaporation of the solvent electron micrographs of the particles retained were taken. A JEM-2010(HR) transmission elector microscope was used. (B) X-ray diffraction (XRD): The catalysts were analyzed by XRD using a D/max-rA XRD instrument (XD-98, Philips, Eindhoven, The Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation (1.5406Å). The accelerating voltage and the applied current were 40kV and 30mA, respectively. The XRD analysis was carried out in two steps. First, we scanned a range of 2θ from 10° to 70° with a rate of 4°/min to observe the overall XRD peaks. Then, in the subsequent analysis, the scan, started from 35° and ended at 48° at a rate of 1°/min, was aimed to calculate the crystallite size of the Au. (C) Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS): The content of residual element (Au or Ce) in the solution after synthesis process was analyzed by ICP-MS instrument (XSENIES, Thermo Fisher Scientific, America). (D) Raman spectra: The Raman spectra were recorded using a LabRamHRUV double spectrometer with a photomultiplier, operating in the photon counting mode. The 514nm line of an Ar+ ion laser was used for excitation. The laser power on the samples was 10mW. The spectral slit width was 1cm−1. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements The catalysis activity measurement was performed at atmospheric pressure in an up-flow tubular reactor (i.d. 4mm) made of stainless steel, loaded typically with 0.05g of powder catalyst diluted with 1.5g of quartz sand in 40–60 mesh. The catalyst was maintained at 400°C for 2h in air flowing at 40mLmin−1. And then, a mixture of 1000ppm of benzene and air flowing at 80mLmin−1 (total WHSV=96,000mLgcat −1 h−1) was switched in to start the reaction. The concentration of benzene in the inlet and outlet was analyzed by on-line GC (model 1102 by ShangFeng) equipped with a FID detector. No organic byproducts for benzene oxidation were detected in the outlet, indicating that benzene was completely oxidized. The reaction temperature was controlled at 400–100°C. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structure characterization Fig. 1A–E showed the TEM pictures of Au catalysts with different NaOH pre-adding fraction in preparation. Fig. 1F showed the HRTEM pictures of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–0%, and the insert was the electron diffraction pattern of CeO2 grains. By measuring the lattice spacing, Au and CeO2 grains could be distinguished well. CeO2 crystals with 2–4nm in diameter dispersed uniformly on silica. The bigger and more fuscous balls were Au. It was clearly found that, Au particle size increased apparently with increase of the NaOH pre-adding fraction, while the feature of CeO2 did not show distinct variation. In ALRT, the pre-adding NaOH changed the reaction environment in adsorbed layer, which affected the hydrolysis process of HAuCl4 remarkably. At higher pH, HAuCl4 was apt to form Au(OH) x Cl− 4–X (X =3–4), which was more easier to be reduced by ethanol, and the Au particles grew bigger. Fig. 2(I) showed the XRD spectra of the catalysts. The peaks at 2θ =38.2°, 44.4°, 64.6° and 77.5° are corresponding to (111), (200), (220) and (311) of Au grains, respectively. The weak peaks at 2θ =28.5°, 47.5°, 56.3° are corresponding to CeO2 grains. With increase in the fraction of pre-added NaOH, the peaks of CeO2 did not show any obvious changes, while the peaks of Au getting more keen-edged. The peaks at 2θ =38.2° and 44.4° of Au were fitted via Cauchy equation, from which the crystallite size of Au was calculated by Scherrer equation. In this paper, our discussion is based on crystallite size calculated from the strongest peak at 2θ =38.2°. As showed in Fig. 2(II), the crystallite size of Au increased apparently, from 8 to 20nm, with increase in the fraction of pre added NaOH. CeO2 crystallite size were also obtained by fitting the peaks of CeO2 at 2θ =47.5° and 56.3°, the results showed that CeO2 crystallites were less than 4nm and not changed with the amount of pre added NaOH. The crystallite size of Au and CeO2 obtained by XRD showed similar tendencies as observed by TEM. 3.2 Catalytic activity measurement The catalytic activity of the catalysts was tested in benzene oxidation and the conversion curves were showed in Fig. 3(I). The catalytic behavior of CeO2 was quite special [3,7,8], implying different mechanisms of benzene oxidation at various temperatures. In our former research [8], T 5 (temperature for 5% benzene conversion) and T 50 were used for the description of low-temperature activity and higher-temperature activity, respectively. In this paper, we used similar method and the obtained T 10 and T 90 were showed in Fig. 3(II). They showed significantly different tendencies: T 90 increased monotonically with increase of NaOH pre-adding fraction, while T 10 firstly decreased and then increased. Compared to Au-free catalyst, the existing Au sharply reduced T 90 from more than 400°C to about 300°C, suggesting a decisive role of Au on high-temperature activity. This was consistent with our previous findings: supported Au produced the conversion plat-form of CeO2/SiO2 catalyst disappeared, which meant apparent improvement in high-temperature activity. Ordinarily, oxidative combustion of hydrocarbons followed Mars–van Krevelan mechanism [11–13]. Lattice oxygen was the active oxygen. Au weakened metaloxygen bond in CeO2 and increased the mobility of lattice oxygen [14–16], thus increased the catalytic activity. The smaller the Au particles were, the more obvious the effect on CeO2 could be. As showed in Fig. 4 , T 90 decreased monotonously with decrease in Au size. T 10 showed a different trend with T 90 and the catalyst 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–0% with smallest Au did not show the best low-temperature activity. Preliminary studies on CeO2/SiO2 confirmed the excellent low-temperature activity of nano-CeO2 prepared by ALRT. Based on the standpoint [3,17] that surface peroxo were responsible for the oxidation of hydrocarbons on ceria below 300°C, we had suggested that smaller ceria with higher surface peroxo content could show better low-temperature activity [8]. According above TEM and XRD, the size of CeO2 showed little variation when the pre adding NaOH changed. For exploring in depth about the microstructure of CeO2, Raman spectroscopy was employed. As showed in Fig. 5 , the strong band at 450–460cm−1 has been attributed to the vibrational mode of the F 2g symmetry, the only Raman-active mode of the perfect cubic fluorite lattice (space group Oh) [18,19]. The very weak bands at 600cm−1 arise from a mixing of E g , and F 2g vibrational modes of the CeO2 lattice. And the weak bands at 1124cm−1 was assigned to the OO stretching vibration of the dioxygen species bound to one-electron defects on the CeO2 surface to form superoxide species, O2− [20,21]. Compared with 9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2, the band at 1124cm−1 was absence in the Raman spectra of Au catalysts and the band at 450–460cm−1 showed apparent red-shift, indicating structure changes of CeO2 grains. There are many factors which could induce the F 2g band shift of CeO2, such as grain size, expansion or shrink of lattice. Lee et al. [22] suggested that when CeO2 size decreased from 5μm to 6nm, the band showed a red-shift from 464cm−1 to 459cm−1. In our former research [8], the band of 18CeO2/SiO2 was at 460cm−1, the same location as the sample with 6nm in Lee's research. It further shifted to 451cm−1 when the sample underwent alcohol-thermal treatment, or to 452.3cm−1 when Au was loaded. Martínez-Arias et al. [23] also suggested that traces of Cu entered the lattice of CeO2 could induce the band shift (CeO2, 464.3cm−1; CuO/CeO2, 461.9cm−1). The shifts in the literature were relatively small, less than 10cm−1. However, the red-shift of 1.5Au–9CeO2/9CeO2/SiO2–10% catalyst was much larger (21.9cm−1). The catalysts were prepared with purpose by coupling the adsorption process of HAuCl4 and the deposition process of CeO2. So, some Au could dope into CeO2 grains, leading increase in the lattice stress. Considering the hydrolysis of HAuCl4 was pH-sensitive, we changed the amount of pre added NaOH. When the fraction of pre added NaOH was 10–15%, Gold(III) chloride would exist in the forms of Au(OH) x Cl− 4−X (X =2–3), which were structural similar with the precipitate of ceria species (Ce(OH)3), and were easier to enter the lattice. Therefore, the red-shift of the catalysts with 10% and 15% of pre added NaOH were the maximum. At higher or lower fraction, the Raman shift getting smaller. The structure changes in CeO2 grains were also evident in the low-temperature activity of benzene oxidation: Raman shift and T 10 showed a similar tendency with the fraction of pre added NaOH (Fig. 6 ). In order to verify the improvement of the low-temperature activity was due to the structure change of CeO2 derived from Au3+ entering CeO2 lattice, other metal ions were doped into CeO2. Fig. 7(I) showed the conversion curves of 18CeO2/SiO2 with different doping ions. The doping of Zr improved low-temperature activity, whereas the doping of Mn or Cu weakened acitivity. A parallel experiment (4CeO2/SiO2 catalyst, Fig. 7(II)) showed the same phenomena. The doping catalysts were also analyzed by Raman spectroscopy. Compared with Au-doping catalysts, the Raman shifts of these doping catalysts were smaller and Fig. 8 showed the relationship between the shifts and T 10. It was found that the low-temperature activity was manifestly influenced by the grain structure of CeO2: when the red-shift of F 2g band was enhanced, the low-temperature activity was improved; when depressed, it was weakened. The different effects of doping ions could attribute to the element properties (Table 1 ). The ions which weakened the low-temperature activity, such as Cu and Mn, were both divalent, far different from Ce in CeO2 which was quadrivalence. As for Zr and Au, the valence state of the former was the same as Ce, and the ionic radius of later was 85pm, close to Ce4+ (87pm). 4 Conclusions A new preparation method, Adsorbed-Layer Reactor Technique, was employed for the synthesis of Au–CeO2/SiO2 catalysts. The grain structure of CeO2 and size of Au were regulated by pre adding part of NaOH before the coupling processes of HAuCl4 adsorption and CeO2 deposition. The results in benzene oxidation tests showed that the high-temperature activity depended on Au size, T 90 increased with Au size increase, while, the low-temperature activity was affected by CeO2. Raman spectroscopy indicated the microstructure of CeO2 was responsible for the improvement of low-temperature catalytic activity. An obvious relevance between the red-shift of F 2g band of CeO2 and the low-temperature activity (T 10) was presented both in NaOH pre-addition experiment and in other metal ion doping experiment. coredata.dc:description: Au–CeO2/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by Adsorbed-Layer Reactor Technique and characterized by TEM, XRD and Raman spectroscopy. It was found the pre-addition of NaOH changed the hydrolysis of HAuCl4 in adsorbed layer and then regulated the morphology and microstructure of Au and CeO2. In the catalysis of benzene oxidation, with the increase of pre-addition amount of NaOH, the high-temperature activity increased monotonously, which was consistent with the change of crystallite size of Au. However, the low-temperature activity presented a maximum with increase of pre-addition amount of NaOH, which was verified being agreement with the change of red-shift of F 2g peak of CeO2. The results showed that the high-temperature activity depended on Au size and the low-temperature activity was affected by CeO2 microstructure. The experiment of metal ion doping offered another proof.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of pre-added NaOH on the microstructure of Au–CeO2 catalyst and its activity for benzene oxidation
